contents.text: Games created through the DALI project are educational games: their primary goal is to make learning a fun experience to optimize knowledge retention. The DALI games have been created so that players can play independently of outside help while also benefiting fully from it: entering the role of facilitator.

Facilitators guarantee that the players are benefiting from the pedagogical aspects of the game they are playing during a game session. They can act as organizers, as referees, as helpers or simple observers. The stance of the facilitator depends entirely on the type of game session being organized, the target audience, their skill level and the goal set for said game session.

Educators, tutors and trainers are the best suited to be facilitators, but it is not mandatory. As long as someone understands the pedagogical benefits and the rules of the educational games, understands the needs of the players and knows how to communicate with them, they can be a facilitator.
Ideally, facilitators should have played the games they intend to use in their game session: a first hand experience of the material that will be used is highly beneficial.

The documents below will help facilitators to frame their training session: the facilitator's guide gives a lot of suggestions in that regard. To learn more about the games and their pedagogical approach, facilitators can also take a look at the handbook.
Both of these documents are available in English, Spanish, German and Norwegian.
